title: culture limits needed tackle online
story: NewsCulture of limits needed to tackle online gambling, says Labours Tom WatsonThe partys Deputy Leader will give a speech outlining plans to clamp down on web-based wagersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  FEB NewsCasino website "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A “culture of limits” on online gambling is needed to tackle the “public health emergency”, Labour says today.Deputy Leader Tom Watson will blast outdated laws as “completely unfit” for an internet-dominated era in a speech to a think tank. Mr Watson, the Shadow Culture Secretary, will tell the Institute for Public Policy Research the  Gambling Act is a piece of “analogue legislation not fit for the digital age”.  Online gambling is “totally lacking adequate regulation”, causing “gross excesses, abuse and vulnerable problem gamblers being let down”, he will warn. Figures from  showed two million gamblers hooked or at risk of addiction, with more than , already deemed problem punters. A surge in the use of smart phones to place wagers has been blamed for a rise in addicts. Mr Watson said: “Problem gambling is Britain’s hidden epidemic, we should treat it as a public health emergency. “Our current gambling laws are completely unfit for the digital age.  “The  Act was written so long ago it has more mentions of the postal service than the internet. “Whereas gambling in the offline world is highly regulated, the lack of controls on online gambling is leading to vulnerable consumers suffering huge losses.” He will highlight cases such as one problem gambler bet pound, a day using stolen money and was made to sign a non-disclosure agreement gagging him from tipping off the Gambling Commission. In another case, a young man with a brain injury lost pound, in just four-months gambling online. Mr Watson will say:“Online gambling companies have a responsibility to protect their customers from placing bets that they cannot afford.

title: theresa avoids damaging commons defeat
story: NewsTheresa May avoids damaging Commons defeat by backing down over citizens’ rightsThe Government supported a powerful bid by Tory MP Alberto Costa to offer guarantees to more than m people in crunch Brexit votesShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May backed down over on citizens’ rights after a No Deal Brexit to avoid yet another damaging Commons defeat.The Government supported a powerful bid by Tory MP Alberto Costa to offer guarantees to more than m people in crunch Brexit votes. But bizarrely the ministerial aide, who has Italian parents, was forced to quit so he could table the amendment. It came after Home Secretary Sajid Javid had backed the move saying there was “nothing wrong” with it. The Brexit U-turn came just  hours after the Prime Minister suggested she could not support his plan.   Mr Costa had urged Mrs May to push for the rights of all British nationals settled in the EU, and EU citizens here, to be ringfenced in a no deal scenario. But she told him: “If it’s not within that withdrawal agreement then it is a matter for inidual states, and we have already taken that up with inidual states.” The Tory MP accused her of hiding behind process. Sources claimed he was later sacked, despite Mr Javid’s support and No  saying the PM didn’t oppose the move.Labour backed his amendment, as well as dozens of Tory backbenchers, including prominent Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg. Shadow home secretary Diane Abbott said his departure would “prolong the anxiety and uncertainty” of .m EU citizens living in the UK and .m Brits on the continent.Mrs May had already taken the sting out of the Brexit votes by vowing to give MPs votes next month on No Deal and delaying Brexit. But she faced pressure from French president Emmanuel Macron who said the UK would need a good reason to postpone its departure beyond March .   He said that any request from Britain would need to be justied by “a clear perspective on the goal,” adding: “We don’t need time, we need decisions.” German Chancellor Angela Merkel, however, said the EU would not oppose any request for an extension. Labour also formally commited to supporting a second referendum after its own Brexit alternative was defeated. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer confirmed Labour would back or table an amendment in favour of a public vote between a deal and Remain.But Jeremy Corbyn ’s spokesman raised Labour temperatures by suggesting “other outcomes” could still be on the table.There were also early signs that some Tory eurosceptics could swing in behind the PM’s deal.

title: universal credit thousands lose cash
story: NewsUniversal Credit: Thousands lose cash as tiny changes force them to new benefitHundreds of thousands are "suffering" by £ a week as changes as small as a childs fth birthday force them to join the six-in-one benefitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsHundreds of thousands are suffering by £ a week thanks to tiny changes like a childs fth birthday "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of thousands of benefit claimants will see their payments cut as they are forced onto Universal Credit by changes as small as their childs fth birthday, MPs were warned today. An expert warned families are suffering under a regime that shunts people onto the six-in-one benefit - without any transition cash. Existing benefit claimants are meant to switch to UC from mid- under a poundbn fund to protect their incomes. Yet families with a change in circumstances are already being moved over - without this protection.  MPs heard these changes can be as simple as a child’s fth birthday, when Income Support ends for some single parents. Policy in Practice warned % of UC claimants will lose out by an average of pound a week compared to the old system.   Meanwhile % are expected to gain by pound a week, the think tank told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee. Policy manager Zoe Charlesworth warned the system has caused some real dficulties for claimants and is much tougher on people forced to move due to a change of circumstances. There are some inidual circumstances where that test and learn approach should be learning - where people are suffering because of the natural migration, she said. Some million people are expected to be on UC by Christmas without any transition payments. While many will be new claimants who werent on benefits before, many others will be moved due to a change of circumstances - known as natural migration. Last month the Mirror revealed more than , parents and workers had been moved from Tax Credits onto UC in this way.   Other changes of circumstances include when people move house, have a break-up, start or stop being a carer or have their first child. Kayley Hignell of Citizens Advice told MPs: All of those people don’t get transitional protection. They are going through a change in circumstances that can be hard. MPs heard people who fail fit-for-work tests for sickness benefit ESA are even choosing to go without cash rather than claim UC. Ms Charlesworth said: They then have a choice - they can either claim UCthey’re putting in an appeal and get some money, or they can live on nothing, hope they get an appeal, and then they’re allowed to get back onto ESA. They have to live with nothing.  They have to make a sort of bet with themselves really on which way it’s going to go. MPs heard poor self-employed people, DLA or PIP disability benefit claimants, and homeowners receiving tax credits are among the groups with the most losers under the scheme. By contrast, the biggest winners include people in work. Kayley Hignell of Citizens Advice called on the government to “slow down natural migration”. She said that could be done through measures like stopping people moving onto UCthey are in the middle of an appeal. David Finch of the Resolution Foundation think tank also suggested ministers “move into slowing down” the process. A DWP spokesperson said: “Only new claimants or people who have undergone a change in circumstances are being asked to apply for Universal Credit. “Jobcentre staff offer support and guidance to people moving onto Universal Credit and more than . million people are now receiving the benefit successfully.”

title: best worst birthday dates revealed
story: NewsBest and worst birthday dates revealed - find outyours is on the listA study found that June  is the top date on the calendar to have come into the world kicking and screamingShareCommentsByLewis Oakley:,  FEB NewsUnsurprisingly, a January birthday is considered one of the worst times in the calendar to emerge into the world "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s official – the best day to have a birthday is  June, according to Brits. A poll of , adults revealed the days we would most – and least – like to be born on. Unsurprisingly, a January birthday is considered one of the worst times in the calendar to emerge into the world. One in seven said they would like their birthday to fall on the summer solstice –  June, which is the longest day of the year. Christmas Day was voted the worst day of the year for your big day to land, followed by a ‘leap year day’ on  February.   The research was undertaken by Dr. Oetker to celebrate the ‘forgotten birthdays’ of Leaplings – a minority of Brits who only officially celebrate their birthday once every four years because they were born on th February, a date that only occurs during leap years. The disadvantages of being born on th February are, according to the poll, not knowing what day to celebrate on , tiring of jokes about their unusual birthdayand missing out on cake . Spokesperson Emma Haworth said: “Most of us take for granted our birthdays happen every year, but what happens to the people born on th February  “While they still have another year to wait to celebrate their birthday, we want to make  their year. Despite missing out on their birthday this year, next year Leaplings will celebrate their special day on a Saturday, which was selected as the best day of the week to have a birthday.   More than half of the population still hope to receive a cake on their special day every year, though  per cent will find themselves having to go without. Over one in six say they like to bake a cake from scratch to make the recipient feel special on their big day. Meanwhile,  per cent of bakers admit to baking birthday cakes because they taste better than ones bought from a shop. Dr. Oetker spokesperson, Emma Haworth added: “The act of baking itself stirs up powerful feelings of happiness and excitement, from the thrill of weighing out ingredients to the first triumphant forkful. “That’s why Dr.Oetker is encouraging people to bake someone’s birthday cake.” Seventy one per cent of Brits believe they are never too old for homemade birthday cake and candles. Six in  Brits believe homemade cakes taste better than shop-bought, and they’re also more likely to bake one for a friend or relative than buy one.   Proving that we’re a nation of chocolate lovers, a chocolate cake was deemed the best birthday cake flavour. This was closely followed by a classic Victoria sponge, then a lemon drizzle and decadent chocolate fudge, according to the OnePoll research. Eighty four per cent insist on having candles on top of their cake, though  per cent wont make a wish when they blow them out. The best thing about birthdays is being surrounded by friends and family, followed by loads of presents and home baked birthday cake.To celebrate Dr Oetker have gted  three-tiered cakes to mark their three quarter-birthday to  ‘Leaplings’ including the UK’s first set of Leapling triplets, India, Savannah and Alicia Philips from Wolverhampton. Dancer, India Philips, who is about to turn , said: ‘I love homemade birthday cakes because it shows that someone has put a lot of thought and care into your birthday to make your day extra special.” Student Savannah Phillips said: I love being a triplet but sometimes we do have to share a birthday cake. I was so happy when my cake arrived. It made my special day even more special.” The Top Ten Reasons Brits Bake a Birthday Cake for a Loved One . Homemade cakes taste better . Shows a special effort . Makes the recipient feel special on their big day . Gives something unique and personal . For the love of baking . The feeling of seeing the one whose birthday it is enjoying a slice of cake . The creative process of baking . It wouldn’t be a birthday without home baked cake . The look on the recipient’s face when a homemade cake is presented . To show off that baking talent

story: NewsFlybe passengers close shave after plane almost crashes at mphThe Flybe plane was approaching George Best Belfast Airport at ,ft when the safety of the aircraft “may have been compromised”ShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  FEB NewsA Flybe aircraft lands at George Best Belfast Airport "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Dozens of Flybe passengers had a close shave when a plane came within a split second of crashing at mph, a report revealed today.The Embraer  was ft away from ploughing into a paraglider eight miles east of George Best Belfast Airport.Belfast Live says the report by the UK Airprox Board blamed the paramotor for flying into conflict” with the twin-engined jet.Flybe flight BE landed safely after the incident at around .pm on August  last year. story: NewsMan ordered to pay £, child support for daughter he didnt know existedRoss Mclaughlan, , from Stockton-on-Tees, County Durham, says he was was shocked when he received the Child Maintenance Service letter telling him he had a teenage daughterShareCommentsByTanveer Mann:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsRoss Mclaughlan, , was shocked when he received the CMS letter in , telling him he had a teenage daughter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn oil rig worker claims he has been ordered to pay pound, in child support to a -year-old daughter he didnt know existed. Ross Mclaughlan, , says he was left speechless when he received a letter from the Child Maintenance Service back in  telling him he had a teenage daughter. The -year-old, from Stockton-on-Tees, County Durham, was not married and claims he had no idea who the girls mum was.He told the Daily Mail : I was so confused and didn’t recognise either the girl’s name or her mother’s, but told myself they’d either got the wrong Ross Mclaughlan, or that someone had targeted me as part of some scam.I was very wrong. It’s eight years since that letter arrived and, despite me never having seen or even spoken to the girl named in it, nor having any contact with her mother, I’ve had pound, deducted from my wages and been told I owe a further pound,.”   Ross says he initially tried to ignore the letter but then decided to pay the pound-a-month sum so it wouldnt jeopardise his job. He refused to take a DNA test as he felt it went against his human rights. But four years ago, he was hit with another letter from the CMS, telling him that the child support costs were increasing to pound a month. If he paid, it would mean he was left with an income of just pound after tax.   So he decided to look into the case further and request a copy of the girls birth certicate, which he says showed a dferent mans name under the father section - one who had the same surname as the girl and her mother. Ross immediately wrote to the CMS hoping that would be enough evidence to prove he wasnt the father and stop the payments. But he received a reply saying the certicate was not enough proof that the man was the child’s biological dad and so the money kept going out of his account. Things got even worse when the daughter turned  and he was told that he would have to pay a further pound, in retrospective payments. Ross described the whole case as being extortion and likened it to something that happens in a fascist state.   The woman claims she fell pregnant after a short fling with Ross and gave birth to their daughter in June . Her ex-husband allegedly became suspicious and requested a DNA test which proved the girl wasnt his, according to the woman. The daughter told the paper that she did wonder why Ross didnt get in touch when he found out about her from the CSA. A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions, which oversees the CMS, said: “We noty people before making deductions, to ensure they have a chance to contest parentage. story: NewsMum horried to discover whats inside bizarre pods she found in her gardenA mum turned to the internet for help after spotting some rather sinister looking pods dangling from a nearby treeShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB NewsA mum found sinister pods on her neighbours tree "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf youve ever seen the  film, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, then youll know you should be y wary of bizarre pods. story: NewsChildren of God cult leader told followers to celebrate God in huge sex orgiesDavid Berg, leader of Children of God cult, shared ways to fantasise about romps with JesusShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  FEB NewsBerg was a cult leader with some odd fantasies "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A notorious cult leader told followers to celebrate God with mass sex orgies and fantasise about romps with Jesus while performing sex acts, a new book claims.David Berg often issued precise instructions to those loyal to the Children of God cult about sexual activity, according to Jo Thornely’s book Zealot. The group sprang up in the US in the s but by  had  communities around the world. Followers were encouraged to imagine Jesus was present when they were having sex. Mr Berg issued a “Mo Letter” containing a list of things you could say to Jesus while you pretended you were making love to him. These included X-rated phrases such as “I receive your love, Lord, with open arms and open legs” and “flood me with your seeds”.    The book alleges Mr Berg was fine with female homosexuality, but described two men making love to one another as “distasteful”. Ms Thornely said: “Women — whether they felt like it or not — were required to share themselves sexually with other men in the Children of God homes. It was considered a duty, and a duty that was only required of women. “Within the Children of God, adult men only had sex when they wanted to, but very frequently, adult women had sex when they didn’t want to and with people they did not want to have sex with.”   Mr Berg, who died in , also instructed women to dance for him, the book alleges. He liked the women to fondle themselves while they danced but any woman who was heavily pregnant or had “sagging breasts” had to cover up. “Thanks to his love of sexism and exploitation, Berg taught his followers that women were made for men. They’re God’s way of saying, ‘Here, I love you, so I made you a thing with boobs on it,’” Ms Thornley added.  Ms Thornley explores ious cults across the world in her book Zealots. The blurb reads: Why would anyone join a cult  Maybe theyre unhappy with their current religion, or they want to change the world, or theyre disappointed with their lives and want to find something bigger or holier that makes sense of this confusing, chaotic and dangerous world. Or maybe they just want to give themselves the best possible chance of having sex with aliens.

The pair missed the Royal Caribbean ship as it pulled out of Nassau on its way back to Miami, USA. With all their luggage on board, the couple - who were dressed for a day in the sun - could do little but shout at the huge boat as it left them behind. They were supposed to be back to the Symphony of the Seas, with the rest of the day trippers, by .pm on Friday, February .  Do you know the couple  Were you on board  Email webnews@mirror   And  minutes later the gangway was removed by the dock crew and the doors were closed on board. But the man and woman, whose nationality is not known, turned up five minutes later only to see the ship preparing to push off. Desperate shouts of No could be heard as they tried to catch the attention of those on board by waving their arms. It is not known why the couple were late orthey had been on an organised tour. The footage which was shared online has been viewed almost a million times, with many cruise lovers giving their opinons.  One popular comment read: :These are the type of people that,you are having a party that starts at pm, you tell them .. And Elyse George added: I just came off a cruise a few days ago. Daily I saw people come back after the cut off time of pm. I saw people coming in between .pm-pm. If you can’t respect the rules you deserve to get left. Jenner Harris added Not that Im rejoicing in their misfortune, but cruises are very scheduled. You have so many hours at port, for meals and for entertainment.   If ships had a reputation for waiting for every person who was late, they would never leave port. Punctuality is the ultimate respect for someone s time. And another added: Every time when we go on a cruise I always make sure I come back super early, my we and I, because I dont want to end up on YouTube looking like these two, like a damn fool.has contacted Royal Caribbean for comment.

title: worlds smallest ever baby survives
story: NewsWorlds smallest ever baby SURVIVES after being born weighing less than lbThe boy, from Tokyo, Japan, is thought to be the smallest newborn boy ever to leave hospital in a healthy condition after he was born weighing just gShareCommentsByTanveer Mann:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe child spent months in an incubator "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA miracle baby boy who was born weighing less than lb has finally gone home in a case thats made medical history. The tiny infant had to spend the first few months of his le in a hospital incubator. The boy, from Tokyo, is thought to be the smallest newborn boy ever to leave hospital in a healthy condition after he was born weighing just g . He was delivered at  weeks by emergency cesarean section in August after he stopped growing in the womb and doctors were concerned his le may be in danger. The baby was so small at birth, he could fit in cupped hands.   But after doctors at Keio Hospital managed his breathing and nutrition over several months, he grew to a healthy lbs and was able to be breastfed. He left the hospital last Wednesday, two months after his initial due date.  Now, the paediatricians who treated the newborn hope this case will give hope to other families of premature babies.Dr Takeshi Arimitsu told Kyodo News : I want people to know that babies canhome vigorous eventhey are born small. The record was previously held by a boy born in Germany in , weighing g , the hospital said, while the smallest girl was born weighing g , also in Germany, in . According to the Tiniest Babies Registry website, only  babies in the world have managed to survive after being born prematurely and weighing under g .

title: bbc should stop its glasgow bias and focus on dundee says homes under the hammer star martel maxwell
story: The BBC should look beyond Glasgow and focus more on Dundee, says Homes Under the Hammer presenter Martel Maxwell.The Dundonian was present at the launch party of the new BBC Scotland channel, which began this week.Martel believes the channel presents an opportunity to do things dferentlyShe wrote in her latest Tele column: #Of course Glasgow will feature more heavily on both ITV and BBC than other parts of the country, as perhaps it should, given it is our biggest city.#It’s also where BBC Scotland and STV have their HQs – and from a budget point of view, it costs more to set studios up or have entire crews travel where.#But bosses are aware Scotland as a whole has to be reflected back to licence payers. This is a chance not just to create jobs in the media, to make new stars and innovative programming it’s an opportunity to regularly visit all of Scotland.#Dundee has been under-represented on Scottish TV and that must change – to reflect not only the fact we are the fourth-largest citybut how great we look and how bright our future is.#If the Antiques Roadshow can do itBBC Scotland certainly can.#

title: blether celtic and arbroath man jimmy bone the hardest opponent
story: In a general conversation about football , I was asked which one player did I find it hard to play against.My answer was instant . . . Jimmy Bone.Now, my encounter was really brief, as I came on as a substitute for East Fe at Partick Thistle in , a game we were to lose -. In my time on the pitch, his movement was such I hadn’t encountered before, and he gave me “a doing”.Many years later, when he was assistant to Jocky Scott at Dens Park, I asked himhe remembered that game.“I do remember that game very well,” he immediately said.“I had just come back from injury at that time and was really buzzing to be back in the team.“I did give the East Fe central defenders a hard time.”Then, looking straight at me, he concluded: “Don’t worry, I would have given anyone a doing on that day.”After he scored well over  goals for Partick Thistle, others noted his form and he soon earned a move to Norwich, then on to Sheffield United.Celtic took him back to Scotland, but he didn’t appear regularly for the Hoops.In , Arbroath paid around £, to Celtic to bring him to Gayfield and then recouped treble that amount three years later when they sold him to Alex Ferguson’s St Mirren.After four years at Love Street, he had spells with Toronto Blizzard and Hong Kong Rangers before spending two years with Hearts and another stint at Arbroath.Bonemoved into management with Arbroath in that second spell, then took charge of Airdrie, St Mirren, East Fe and Stenhousemuir.In addition to his coaching stint at Dens, he enjoyed similar posts at Ross County, Partick Thistle and Chester City. Other appointments took him abroad to Zambiaand Bidvest Wits .

title: gordon forrest says dundee united fans vital in championship promotion push
story: Dundee United fans have been told they’re not just appreciated, they’ll be vital as the Championship promotion race reaches its climax.That’s the view of Tangerines assistant boss Gordon Forrest, who admits since ing to Scottish football last month he’s been blown away by the level of support Arabs give their team.Well over , headed for Falkirk on Saturday and, despite a small travelling support expected and the top two in the ision meeting in Dingwall, tonight’s clash with Inverness Caley Thistle at Tannadice will boast the biggest turnout in the second tier.While those kind of crowds can have a positive effect on the opposition, Gordon believes the positives of being the best-supported team in the ision easily outweigh any negatives.“The fans have been absolutely magnicent, particularly in the away games,” said the former Vancouver Whitecaps coach.“When the players are coming out for their warm-up, during the game, you can see the stands are packed. The fans are singing, they’re cheering and it just makes a massive dference for the players.“When we go back to Tannadice the noise levels there have been great. We appreciate it as a club and I know the players do.“When we play against teams they do pick up to their maximum in terms of their performance, they raise their game a little bit but it helps us in that push to pick up the points in the run-in.”Tonight, United will be without defender Freddy Frans after he had to come off with a groin injury at the weekend.He will see a specialist about the problem and, while United are hopeful he will not be out for too long, he has no chance of making tonight or Sunday, when the teamsto Tannadice to battle it out in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals.Rachid Bouhenna came on for Frans then had to go off late on with a facial injury, but could be OK.“Freddy is probably looking at a longer time out. In terms of finer detail and the number of days or weeks it’s hard to say just now,” added Gordon.“With Rachid, there was a lot of blood and a cut on the nose. You’ve got to be careful with that. Hopefully he can be patched up and be in the mix.”

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness College students showcase work of Highland Hospice
story: DRAMA students at Inverness College UHI have teamed up with Highland Hospice to offer insight into the patient experience of palliative care.Third year BAdrama and performance students performed Homeward Bound, a -minute play charting one couplersquos experience of end-of-le care, after being approached by the hospice.Officials at the hospice were keen to see live drama used as an educational tool to help improve the quality of palliative care and the experience of those involved.The play was performed to staff and nursing and care students at the college, with hospice representatives providing commentary to provide context and insight into the experience.It proved such a useful educational tool, the drama students have been asked to perform the play again at the NHS Highland Highland Hospice Essentials in Palliative Care Conference at Eden Court in Inverness, on March -, where it will be filmed to be used in learning.Lesley Mickel, programme leader for the drama course, said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with Highland Hospice to develop this special performance, which really highlights the human impact of late diagnosis and the importance of quality palliative care.ldquoIt was not only a challenge for our students in terms of portraying these very raw, human emotions, it also proved an extremely useful educational tool for students studying other parts of the university curriculum, with our nursing and care students gaining a much greater understanding of the issues involved.Hospice learning and development practice lead Siobhan Neylon said: ldquoIt was such an honour to work with these wonderful students on this poignant and emotive drama.ldquoThey portrayed the characters in such a dignied way.Homeward Bound was written by playwright Brian Daniels and tells the true story of Lesley and her husband Seth Goodburn, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer at the age of . He died just  days after diagnosis.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Success sees Inverness Town House tours extended
story: POPULARITY has prompted the number of guided tours of Inverness Town House to double this summer.City councillors have agreed to add two more tours each week after positive feedback.The tours were introduced in June in a move which completed a so-called cultural triangle which includes the cityrsquos museum and Inverness Castle Viewpoint.Two tours on Thursdays have been run by High Le Highlandand proved logistically and financially viable ndash making a pound. profit ndash with the additional two tours on Tuesdays starting on from May .Tours have not disrupted any business in the building and visitors have found them engaging, informative and entertaining.Inverness provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoWell done to High Le Highland and in particular their team of guides, who helped the council create a third, new, visitor attraction in the town house, which along with the museum and art gallery and castle viewpoint have created an accessible lsquocultural trianglersquo around the Castle Wynd area.ldquoAs we move towards the redevelopment of Inverness Castle as a new lsquomust-seersquo visitor attraction, the Town House Tours will complement the tourism offering in this city centre location.HLH chief executive Ian Murray said: ldquoHigh Le Highland has been delighted to work with the council to create public access to the splendid town house and we look forward to seeing visitor numbers and tour provision increasing this summer.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: aberdeen woman shares secret of long life on 100th birthday
story: A north-east woman celebrating her th birthday believes the secret to a long le is “being well looked after”.Centenarian Ruby Middleton, who lives at Angusfield House care home in Aberdeen, celebrated her milestone birthday yesterday.Ruby, who has lived at the home since  after leaving her lelong home on a farm near Bucksburn, admitted she does not feel , saying “it just feels like another day”.When asked how she had lived such a long le, Ruby said: “I’ve been well looked after.”She received the traditional birthday card from the Queen and enjoyed a small celebration with residents and staff.She was also greeted by the Deputy Lord Lieutenant of Aberdeen Michael Hastie and Jeremy Richardson, the chief executive of Angusfield House’s operator Brighterkind.Mr Hastie said: “It’s amazing to see these people at that age. I have been to a few th birthday celebrations but Ruby really is remarkable.“She seemed like she was really enjoying herself. It looked as though she was liking the company and it was a really special day for her.“To make it to  years old is pretty good. I know they say we are living longer these days but it is still an amazing milestone.”Mr Richardson added: “It’s lovely to be able to celebrate Ruby’s birthday with her because it is a very special occasion.“It’s great to see her looking so happy and well at .”Staff at Angusfield House said former seamstress Ruby is a popular figure with carers and residents and always maintains a positive outlook.Activities coordinator Sandra Fyfe said: “Ruby came to us in May . She is always smiling and she is a very gentle lady.“She still gets visited by her old neighbours and they always make a point of saying how nice she was.“She’s a very friendly lady and loves chatting away.“Prior to coming in she loved flower arranging and she still talks about her garden.“The fact she is still on her feet and is able to get about with her Zimmer is amazing.“She broke her hip last year and we were quite worried about her, butanything, she was back on her feet too quickly. She didn’t let it get in the way of her living le to the fullest.“She’s just lovely.”Care assistant Elaine McConnachie added: “Ruby still loves sewing and she will always pick up a needle and threadshe sees a button coming away.“It’s always lovely to see her and she always puts a smile on your face.”

title: changes in jet stream set to bring colder weather to north east

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. title: districts week 08
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA poem a dayDo you like poetry  Or would you like to spend a little time listening to your own heart  Spring-time is marked out for reflection, new growth and the warmth of generosity in the Christian tradition. It is the time of Lent: the old Germanic word for spring-time. Our hearts are bidden to imitate the snow-drops: to come up from the darkness, raise themselves into the sunlight, and then fill the world with gladness.Parishioners from Ardrishaig, Christ Church, Lochgilphead and Glassary are joining together this Lent to read a poem a day through the  days of Lent and then Easter week. The poems have been chosen are in a beautul book, entitled The Heart’s Time, by Janet Morley. The poems come from across the English-speaking world, over the last four centuries. One poem is set for each day, accompanied by a short explanation, a reflection, and a brief suggestion for our own thinking.Parishioners will be reading the poems at home for those who wish it there will be meetings to share thoughts and inspiration at Ardrishaig Church during the weeks of Lent and at Christ Church on Sundays. Other meetings could be arranged, formally or informally.You can order the book from Fr Simon Mackenzie by emailing dr.lachlan@zen or calling  , or directly from Argyll Book Centre. Lent begins this year on Ash Wednesday March .E.ON donated to Arrochar roof insulationVehicles used by the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team will benefit from being garaged at a more constant temperature this winter after the E.ON Energising Communities Fund paid for £, worth of insulation to be fitted at the rescue post.The volunteers making up the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team provide search and rescue assistance throughout Strathclyde when requested by Police Scotland and can be called upon  hours a day,  days a year.  Working across all mountainous terrain and in any weather condition, they use three vehicles which are kept in the garage attached to the mountain rescue post in Arrochar which was built in .After mechanics identied condensation and corrosion as the cause of the vehicles’ increasingly frequent and expensive mechanical and electrical problems, heating was installed at the garage last year to reduce their maintenance costs and improve their reliability. It was then realised that roof insulation was necessary to lower the cost of the heating.Douglas Philp, team secretary for Arrochar Mountain Rescue, said: #As a charity, we’re totally dependent on donations, grants and volunteers. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby
