title: glasgow-airport-to-paisley-gilmour-street-transport-link-to-be-explored
story: A direct rail link to Glasgow Central station was announced as part of thepound. billion Glasgow City Region deal agreed in  and was expected to be operational by .However, following analysis of the proposals, concerns were raised regarding several aspects of such a link.These included its funding, sustainability and economic impact, as well as the capacity issues at Glasgow Central.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesSpeaking at the Scottish Parliament on Wednesday,Glasgow City Council leader Susan Aitken said that a joint-executive steering groupwould evalaute alternative options for improving airport connectivity.Ms Aitken said: ldquoThere will be an airport link. It will, probably, be a dferent project from the outlined business case that was passed by the City Region Cabinet in .ldquoI think itrsquos fair to say that Transport Scotland always had signicant concerns about the impact on Central Station capacity, in particular, of an additional line.ldquoThere was an agreement to commission a report to look into the details of that business case and when that report came out, I think itrsquos fair to say that it raised very, very signicant challenges on a number of levels.ldquoThe conclusion that we came to was an alternative option that would be linking the airport directly with, probably, Paisley Gilmour Street in the way that, for example, Gatwick North terminal is linked to the railway station at Gatwick South terminal.ldquoSo with some kind of Personal Rapid Transitsystem, of which there are ious options, a small tram or shuttle type arrangement, with Paisley Gilmour Street essentially becoming the airport station and then people connecting into existing rail services to make their way into, not just the city centre of Glasgow, but other parts of the city region.No, it was your shuttle connecting the north terminal to the south terminal and the station I was referring to. Thanks though!mdash Susan AitkenFebruary , ldquoThat was one of the options which was looked into at the time, there was no outline business case taken forward for it so what wersquove now agreed is that we will take forward a fuller business case for that and look into whether thatrsquos a feasible option.Under the original proposals, as set out in the City Regions deal, work on the link was to begin in  and be fully operational by .Ms Aitken indicated that the timescale for revised proposals would not change from those that had been previously set out.She said:ldquoAnything that is more of a national strategic transport project will have a dferent timeline and thatrsquos obviously still to be developed.ldquoBut we would expect it to happen within exactly the same timeline.Read more of todays top Glasgow stories

title: hes-the-right-man-for-the-job-celtic-fans-rejoice-as-neil-lennon-arrives-at-parkhead-as-new-boss
story: Lennon has been installed as manager with John Kennedy his assistant and Damien Duff promoted to first-team coach after a short stint in charge of the reserves.The former Celtic captains extraordinarycapped off a whirlwind  hours after it emerged Celtic had "very reluctantly" given Rodgers permission to speak to Leicester.:New boss Brendan Rodgers post-match speech had Leicester buzzingLennon won three league titles and two Scottish Cups in just over four years as Celtic manager after taking over from Tony Mowbray, initially on a temporary basis, in March .This is what Celtic fans have been saying at Parkhead as Lennon arrived there earlier today:Margaret Rose Watt, , retiredAbsolutely delighted that Lennon has become as club manager. title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

title: wait-for-sentencing-guidelines-branded-unacceptable
story: The Lord Justice Clerk Lady Dorrian, the chair of the Scottish Sentencing Council, said rushed advice could backfire on iniduals and the justice system as as whole.Lady Dorrian spoke out ahead of a Labour-led debate at Holyrood today condemning the councilrsquos failure to produce guidance on sexual assaults, despite a rise in cases.Although the Council has started work on the subject, its guidance will not be ready until after .Labour last week urged the body to prioritise sexual assault guidance after the Christopher Daniel case.The -year-old dental student from Glasgow was granted an absolute discharge last month despite being found guilty of repeatedly sexually assaulting a six-year-old girl.Sherf Gerald Sinclair ruled that Daniel had been motivated by ldquoentirely inappropriate curiosity rather than sexual gratication, and the girl ldquoappeared to have suffered no injury or long lasting effects.Labour will urge MSPs to condemn the ldquounacceptable timescale for the new guidelines.MSP Daniel Johnson said: ldquoWe need to reform and improve sentencing policy in Scotland, ensuring there is transparency in the system so that victims and their families can have confidence in it.ldquoThat starts with Holyrood accepting there is an issue.The Scottish Government will try to amend Labourrsquos motion to commend the councilrsquos ldquoinitial focus of its work on sexual offences and urge ldquoconsensus on the subject.In a y response to vote, Lady Dorrian stressed the Councilrsquos work was based on extensive evidence taking and careful consideration of all aspects of the issues involved.She said: ldquoWhile we do not anticipate guidelines on sexual offences being finalised during the current business plan period [-], this is not a delay but simply reflects the Councilrsquos current work programme and the likely work involved in addressing this subject.ldquoWe have already held initial discussions with the judiciary and with a range of organisations with interest and experience in the sentencing of sexual offences, including victim support organisations, and we have begun research into public views in this area.ldquoIt is likely that the Council will develop multiple guidelines on sexual offending, and we hope to announce the areas of initial focus soon. It is vital that any guidelines we produce are well-researched and fit for purpose.Reflecting on another aspect of the Daniel case, Tory MSP Liam Kerr added: ldquoIt is astonishing that the sexual assault of a six year old has led to no criminal conviction and no punishment. It should be easier for lenient sentences to be appealed in the public interest ndash and the Scottish Law Commission should consider reviewing this area.

title: tory-brexiters-cry-betrayal-after-theresa-may-u-turns-on-delaying-eu-withdrawal
story: In tense Commons exchanges, Peter Bone, the Northamptonshire MP, told the Prime Minister: "She has said  times we will leave the EU on March . If thats not possible, doesnt she think the country will regard that as a betrayal "Jacob Rees-Mogg, Chairman of the European Research Group of Leave-backing Tory MPs, said: "My suspicion is that any delay to Brexit is a plot to stop Brexit. This would be the most grievous error that politicians could commit."The backlash to Mrs Mayrsquos dramatic move came as a UK Government analysis on a no-deal scenario warned Britons were largely not prepared for such an outcome, which would result in higher food prices, delays at Dover lasting months and an extra pound billion hit in costs to businesses.In yet another twist to Westminsterrsquos Brexit drama, the PM changed tack less than  hours after insisting a delay would be pointless and she was determined Britain would leave the EU on the scheduled date of March  with a deal.Her cave-in came after it emerged  rebels had secretly met the night before in the Commons to discuss how to stop a no-deal outcome with as many as  said to be prepared to resign.Three ministers, Claire Perry, Richard Harrington and Margot James went public to ldquoimplore Mrs May to extend the Article  processher deal were rejected by Parliament by March . It followed a similar request at the weekend by three Secretaries of State - Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke - who were denounced by one colleague as ldquokamikaze Cabinet ministers.Earlier this month, The Herald revealed how a Cabinet minister had predicted the PM would come up with a last-minute ldquoform of words to allay ministersrsquo fears to make clear Britain would not leave on March  without a deal.In a Commons statement ahead of yet another next steps vote today, the PM said she appreciated how MPs from all parties were ldquogenuinely worried that time was running out and,the Government lost another meaningful vote, Parliament would not have time to make its voice heard on the next steps.So she pledged to give three further commitments:*to hold a second meaningful vote on the Governmentrsquos new plan by Tuesday March * the Government lost that vote, it would table a motion to be voted on by Wednesday March , askingMPs supported leaving the EU without a deal and* MPs rejected the Governmentrsquos proposal and a no-deal outcome, then they would vote on a ldquoshort limited extension to Article .Mrs May made clear: ldquoSo the UK will only leave without a deal on March ,there is explicit consent in this House for that outcome.But she pointedly refused to say how she would vote on the second key vote: on leaving without a deal.Labourrsquos Owen Smith accused the PM of carrying out a "screeching U-turn" and asked: "Could she be clear - because she hasnt been thus far -we have that vote on March  or , will her Government be voting in favour of no-deal or against it "The PM replied: "Im getting conflicting views from across the chamber on one hand, Im told nothing has changed, on the other hand, Im told weve done a U-turn."Quizzed about why Mrs May had changed course, her spokesman insisted it had nothing to do with ministerial threats of resignation but an ldquoacknowledgement of strong views on all sides of the argument.In her statement, the PM insisted she did not want to extend Article  and her ldquoabsolute focus was on getting a deal by March .However, she pointed out an extension beyond the end of June would mean the UK taking part in the European Parliament elections and asked: ldquoWhat kind of message would that send to the more than  million people who voted to leave the EU nearly three years ago now Mrs May claimed a short extension would ldquoalmost certainly have to be a one-off and would create a ldquomuch sharper clf-edge in a few monthsrsquo time.Across the dispatch box Jeremy Corbyn denounced her ldquogrotesquely reckless" delays.He told MPs: ldquoThe Prime Minister continues to say it is her deal or no-deal but this House has decisively rejected her deal and has clearly rejected no-deal. It is the Prime Ministers obstinacy that is blocking a resolution."Ian Blackford claimed Mrs May "could not be trusted" not to "dodge" another meaningful vote.The SNP leader said it was the ldquoheight of irresponsibility for any government to threaten its citizens with the consequences of a no-deal Brexit."Rule out no-deal, extend Article  but do it today this should not be left until the middle of March," declared the Highland MP.The PM explained the deal would not be brought back to MPs until March  because the Government was still negotiating.ldquoIf he wants to end the uncertainty and deal with the issues he raised...then he should vote for a deal. Simples," she added.Ken Clarke, the former Chancellor, asked about theof any delay, saying: "She seems to be giving us a date for a new clf-edge at the end of June but isnt the danger that we will merely continue the present pantomime performance through the next three months and the public will be dismayed as we approach that date and find there is similar chaos about where were going."Mrs May made clear she wanted any extension to be ldquoas short as possible.Later, her spokesman was asked what would happenMPs voted against all three options - the PMrsquos new plan, a no-deal Brexit and extending Article  - he replied: ldquoThat would be quite contradictory and an unexpected thing to happen.

title: energy-giant-plans-hefty-investment-in-windfarms-and-car-chargers-in-scotland
story: The Glasgow-based energy giant said it wants to play a key role in the push to reduce carbon emissions by helping electry the economy where it matters most: in transport and heating.Read more: Energy price cap branded con as Scots energy bills set to riseThe company and big six rivals came under fire last week for announcing price rises after Ofgem said it would lt the cap on charges.ScottishPowers programme will involve the Spanish-owned group investing in generating more renewable energy and in the facilities required to help ensure consumers make the most of its potential.The company said it will start installing fast chargers across the UK at strategic commercial locations from winter  in a move it reckons will unlock the market for electric vehicle ownership.It is understood this will involve installing kit in places that would allow drivers to make charging their cars part of their routine, such as out of town shopping centres.ldquoOnshore wind remains the lowest cost technology for new electricity generation in the UK and ScottishPower sees substantial opportunities for the continued development of onshore wind projects across Scotland and other areas of the UK, said the company.ScottishPower also announced plans to develop a pioneering battery storage project at the giant Whitelee onshore windfarm on Eaglesham Moor south of Glasgow, which is the biggest in the UK. This could be used to ensure power is available to meet iations in demand.The company said the large-scale battery project will be the first of a series of storage schemes in the UK, which will be mainly located at windfarms and at strategic points on the network.Read more: ScottishPower boss hails pivotal year as profits rise %It reckons the combination of renewable energy and flexible storage provides the most cost-effective low carbon solution for consumers.ScottishPowerrsquos offshore wind development effort is focused on the waters off eastern England.The  investment plan is expected to result in the company creating around  jobs, a signicant number of which will be in Scotland.Chief executive Keith Anderson said the plan was a historic milestone for ScottishPower and provided a vote of confidence in the UKrsquos commitment to decarbonising the economy. ScottishPower invested pound.bn in clean energy in .ldquoConsumers want and need access to reliable, clean and affordable energy, he said. ldquoThat is what ScottishPower is focused on delivering and as long as Government climate change commitments stay firm, with sensible policies to support them, this investment will continue.The company expects to spend poundbn in the UK between  and .It unveiled the investment plan days after posting a  per cent increase in profits, to pound.bn, for . Mr Anderson said the year had been pivotal for the company.The firm completed the ldquolandmark journey from coal and gas to % green power by selling its conventional generation business to Drax for poundm in October.Read more: Power gianteyes growth in Scotland after poundm move into countryThe unit includes a giant reservoir-based power generator in Argyll, the Lanark and Galloway hydro-electric facilities on rivers in South West Scotland and a biomass fuel plant near Glasgow, along with four gas-fired power stations in England.Drax said yesterday the assets were highly complementary to its strategy and would form a very important part of its portfolio. The company expects the assets to provide high quality earnings.It aims to support the move to renewables by investing in generating and storage facilities that will complement wind and solar output.Drax has adapted the giant coal-fired power station in Yorkshire from which it takes its name to run partially on wood pellets.The head of its power generation business, Andy Koss, said the company was very pleased with the assets acquired from ScottishPower. It could invest signicant amounts in developing them with the right official support.Mr Koss highlighted the role the Cruachan pumped storage facility in Argyll played in ensuring supplies are made available to the national grid when needed.Read more: How Cruachan power plant worksCruachan generates power based on the movement of water between a reservoir in the hills and Loch Awe, which lies around  metres below.Mr Koss said Drax is considering development options for Cruachan that could include hollowing out the mountain to build a new turbine hall or constructing a new dam.Drax grew underlying profits by % to poundm last year.Last week ScottishPower said it was raising its prices for customers on standard iable tarfsby  per cent - pound a year . The increase will mean its standard plan for duel fuel customers will cost on average pound,.Other members of the big sixhave increased prices for customers on SVTs recently sinceOfgem decided to raise the typical limit for UK default and standard iable gas and electricity tarfs by pound to pound, a year from April .ScottishPowerrsquos parent group, Iberdrola, said yesterday it would invest eurobnby  to speed growth. It reckons the plan will provide a major boost to the irreversible transition to a low carbon-energy model.

title: scottish-wildcat-population-no-longer-viable
story: A report into efforts to preserve the few remaining Highland Tigers found that the number left in the wild is now too low to represent a "viable" population. Fewer than  are thought to remain in the wild.Efforts should now be focussed on revitalising the species through captive breeding programmes or re-introducing wildcats from northern Europe.Once wide-ranging across much of rural Scotland, the last wildcats are now confined to isolated pockets of the Highlands.Wildcat numbers have fallen to unsustainable levelsHybridisation ndash the breeding of domestic pet and feral cats with wildcats ndash and a loss of habitat have been blamed for the species decline.Other factors were said to be road traffic accidents and dwindling food sources, and efforts to keep down other predators which inadvertently targeted wildcats.Ongoing efforts to preserve populations in the wild have also failed, although population estimates may have been too high to begin with.: Saving the wildcathellip now only a whisker away from extinctionThe study was carried out by International Union for Conservation of Nature rsquos Cat Specialist Group at the behest of Scottish Wildcat Action , starting last year and examining all the current data on wildcats and the ious efforts to preserve the species.It said: "All the robust information available indicates that the wildcat in Scotland is at the verge of extinction."Based on the available information, we consider the wildcat population in Scotland to be no longer viable."The number of wildcats is too small, the hybridisation too far advanced and the population too fragmented."The report added: "We therefore conclude that it is too late to conserve the wildcat in Scotland as a stand-alone population."Conservationists say they will battle on to preserve wildcatsThe elusive wildcat has long been one of the UKrsquos most endangered mammals. Previous studies have cited hybridisation as the major threat to their survival in the wild, but this is the first time researchers have concluded it has contributed to the species dying out on a genetic level.:Claws are out in battle to save Scottish wildcat from extinction#Scottish Wildcat Action Steering Group Chair, Dr Andrew Kitchener, Principal Curator of Vertebrates at National Museums Scotland said: ldquoWe now have the strongest and most reliable evidence to date that wildcats are in a more endangered state than previously understood."While we believe there are wildcats remaining in the wild in Scotland, there are no longer enough to ensure their continued survival as viable populations."However, options are now being examined to revitalise populations in the wold, possibly by introducing wildcats captured in northern Europe, or through a breeding programme with captive-bred wildcats.Dr Kitchener said: "We can now plan the essential next steps to give the wildcat a sustainable future.RZSS CEO Barbara Smith, SNHs Head of People  Nature, Eileen Stuart, and Scotlands Environment Secretary, Roseanna Cunningham. Pic: SNH Lorne Gill.Roseanna Cunningham, the Scottish Governments Cabinet Secretary for the Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform, also pledged not to give up the fight.She said: ldquoThis report presents us with further evidence of the serious challenges that wildcat conservation faces in Scotland."The wildcat is an iconic Scottish species and, as such, I will consider every possible action the Scottish Government can take to save it, including an increased focus on captive breeding and reinforcement of the Scottish population with wildcats from where."We have in place a partnership of scientists and specialists with the knowledge and expertise to give us the best chance of restoring the Highland Tiger as a distinctive and charismatic species in the Scottish countryside, and I look forward to working with them to make this a reality.A wildcat, most likely a hybrid, spotted on Mull. Pic: Peter Harris PACat Conservation Project Officer at the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland, David Barclay, added: ldquoWe know the road ahead for wildcat recovery will be challenging, but our strong partnerships with SWA and international conservation specialists give us an incredible opportunity for success.ldquoOur plans for a National Wildle Reintroduction Centre at Highland Wildle Park will provide the perfect environment for breeding genetically tested wildcats with the aim of releasing them back to the wild to re-establish viable populations in key locations.:Wildcat kittens could provide leline for species#ldquoCombined with the continued development of the conservation breeding programme, this will ensure we have a long-term solution for the recovery and conservation of this iconic species.ldquoTogether we can restore Scotlands wildcats to their rightful place as an integral link in a thriving ecosystem.

title: five-stars-the-dark-carnival-tramway-glasgow
story: The Dark CarnivalTramway, GlasgowNeil CooperFive starsSomething is stirring beneath the cold, dark earth in Vanishing Pointrsquos rollicking graveyard opera, brought to le by director Matthew Lenton in an epic co-production with the Citizens Theatre in association with Dundee Rep. There are bodies asleep in coffins piled on top of each other as Elicia Dalyrsquos narrator wanders into the light, before Bf Smith and his pasty-faced street corner cabaret band strike up the first of a string of chansons that soundtrack a night of the undead. Above them, mourners pay assorted respects to their loved ones. Higher still, drunken angels keep their own council, enjoying the fruits of their out of touch immortality.What emerges out of designer Kenneth MacLeodrsquos magnicent funereal set is a series of noisy visual tableaux to accompany the live music inbetween rhymed exchanges between the eccentric members of an accidentally thrown together underground community. With the sixteen-strong ensemble swathed in celestial light and shade conjured up by Simon Wilkinson, this makes for a slow-burning meditation on le, death and the messy bits inbetween, where any chance of resting in peace is unlikely.As with much of Vanishing Pointrsquos previous work, there is plenty to reflect on here about loss and grieving. This lends a poignancy to things, especially as related in Dalyrsquos magnicently quasi-Dickensian delivery. This time out, however, there is a kind of bittersweet acceptance and a playful levity pulsing things. So while there are ghosts haunting them all, from Malcolm Cummingrsquos Young John and Peter Kellyrsquos Old Peter who mourns him, the peace they crave is enlivened by a song and dance routine to brighten up their sorry start of affairs.It takes the young, embodied here in the spirit of Olivia Barrowcloughrsquos Little Annie, to fight the collective inertia which binds them. From here, they rise up against those on high and storm Heavenrsquos gates, as each and everyone sings out for the great refusal, and for the joy of le itself.

title: mccrone-reacts-as-famous-scottish-independence-oil-report-published-in-newspaper
story: Professor Gavin McCrone said the situation had ldquocompletely changed, while plummeting oil prices in the second half of the s meant the massivesurplus would not have lasted.His comments came as the pro-independence National newspaper published the McCrone report, which was written and researched in  as a briefing to ministers before Labour took power, in its entirety.Prof McCrone, who was then a senior civil servant, told The Herald: ldquoWe had a situation in the s when there were enormous oil discoveries going on all the time, and the revenues were going to be very large.ldquoBut today, we are in a situation where the oil is declining in importance and the revenues have come a way down. The price, well ndash theyrsquove gone up slightly a bit, I suppose, but they will never be what they were.He said his analysis of Scotlandrsquos ldquoembarrassing surplus would not have lasted, because ldquothe oil price came rattling down in the second half of the s.He added: ldquoIt might have been the case at the time. I think these things were probably put in my report to make ministers wake up to the importance of the thing.The -year-old said oil was ldquostill important, but itrsquos nothing like as important as it was back then.Prof McCronersquos  report said the discovery of North Sea oil had ldquocompletely overturned the traditional economic arguments used against Scottish nationalism.It added: ldquoAn independent Scotland could now expect to have massive surpluses both on its budget and on its balance of payments and with the proper husbanding of resources this situation could last for a very long time into the future.It said that ldquofor the first time since the Act of Union was passed, it can now be credibly argued that Scotlandrsquos economic advantage lies in its repeal.Elsewhere, it stated: ldquo[An independent Scotland] would tend to be in chronic surplus to a quite embarrassing degree and its currency would become the hardest in Europe, with the exception perhaps of the Norwegian kroner.The report was classied as ldquosecret and given a restricted circulation because of the "extreme sensitivity of the subject", and only came to light in  following a Freedom of Information request by an SNP researcher.Prof McCrone said he was surprised by the totemic place it now holds in Scottish debate as he did not think it would see the light of day, but said he never felt it was hushed up.He said: ldquoMy thing was never intended to be published. It was a confidential report for ministers ndash these things always are, protected by ious rules.He added: ldquoI didnrsquot expect it to be published. I didnrsquot write it to be published. And I didnrsquot really expect it to be leaked either ndash maybe I should have thought it might have been, but it wasnrsquot.He said he was abroad when the report was initially released in full  years ago, and was ldquoquite amused to come back and find it being discussed.But Prof McCrone said he still believed in setting up an oil fund, even"you wouldnt have nearly so much to put into it now".He said such a move in the s would have ldquomade the situation much easier when we got to the financial crashes.He said: ldquoThe danger when you have a very wealthy resource like that is it crowds out the rest of the economy, of course, and that would have been something that would have had to be facedScotland had been independent.ldquoNorway took measures to deal with that, more or less successfully, but Irsquom not sure whether Scotland would have done. One just doesnrsquot know. The UK didnrsquot really.He continued: ldquoI thought Norway were very sensible with what they did. But then they are a dferent country from the UK.ldquoNorway is a country with a population about the size of Scotland, and the UK had a population of between  and  million I think, at that time, and had a lot of problems.ldquoThe s were a very, very dficult period for any government, whichever government was in office, and so itrsquos perhaps understandable that they just wanted to take advantage of the oil revenues and that was that.

title: trade-union-donations-to-labour-reach-record-low
story: The total of pound. million received from the partys traditional backers was the lowest in any year since Electoral Commission records started in .The commission revealed donation totals for the final three months of last year, which showed Theresa Mays Conservatives taking in almost pound. million - more than four times the amount to Jeremy Corbyns party.Labours pound. million in donations over the fourth quarter was outstripped by the pound,, it received from public funds, much of it made up of the "Short money" provided to help opposition parties fund their work in the Commons.Read more:Jeremy Corbyn warned Peoples Vote sht will have catastrophic electoral consequences for LabourThe pound. million received by Labour from unions compares with almost pound million during the election year of , around pound million in  and pound million in .Labour received more than pound million a year from unions in non-election years under Ed Milibands leadership.The pound,, received by Tories made up almost three-quarters of the total pound,, donated to political parties in Britain in the last three months of the year.In the same period, Sir Vince Cables Liberal Democrats received pound, in donations and pound, from public funds.The figures mean that over the course of  Conservatives took in donations totalling more than pound million, compared with less than pound million for Labour and pound. million for the Lib Dems.Read more:Ian Austin becomes latest MP to quit Labour partyThe biggest gt to the Tories in the fourth quarter was pound. million from musical theatre producer John Gore, a regular donor to the party. Construction vehicle manufacturer JCB gave pound, and former Tory treasurer Michael Spencers IPGL gave pound,.Labours biggest donor was the Unite union, with a pound, gt.The Scottish National Partys pound, in gts from just three donors over the three-month period was dwarfed by the pound, received from public funds.Greens took in pound, in donations and pound, from public funds, and Plaid Cymru had just one donation of pound, and took pound, from public funds.The UK Independence Party received just pound, in donations.

title: sajid-javid-stuns-mps-by-backing-bid-to-secure-eu-citizens-rights-after-no-deal-after-theresa-may-dismissed-it
story: :Theresa May attacks SNP over workplace parking taxThe Prime Minister was expected to go down to defeat in the Commons on Wednesday on the amendment from Tory MP Alberto Costa, after Jeremy Corbyn announced that Labour would support it.Mr Costas office was unable to confirm or deny reports that the South Leicestershire MP was standing down as a parliamentary aide to Scotland Secretary David Mundell in order to push his plan.Mr Javid appeared to be caught by surprise while answering questions before a parliamentary committee to hear that his support for the move was not shared by Mrs May.He told the Home Affairs Select Committee there was "nothing" wrong Mr Costas proposals.Asked by SNP committee member Stuart McDonald whether the Government was now supporting them, he replied: "Yes, what do you mean now  When was the Government not supporting it  When did you hear that "When Mr McDonald said "Yesterday", Mr Javid asked: "From who "The SNP MP replied: "The Prime Minister."A visibly nonplussed Home Secretary replied: "Did you  Right... Oh... OK. Im perfectly happy with the amendment."What Mr Costa is doing, which I think is perfectly correct, is trying to find more ways for Parliament to give that reassurance."More than  Conservatives are among the  MPs who have signed the amendment, which calls for a separate agreement with the European Union to protect the rights of expats eventhere is a no-deal Brexit.Among those signing are former leader Iain Duncan Smith, European Research Group chair Jacob Rees-Mogg and leading pro-EU Tories like Dominic Grieve.:McCrone reacts as famous Scottish independence oil report published in newspaperAfter Labour announced it was supporting the amendment, Mr Costa said it would be a "farce"the Government did not back down.He told the Press Association on Tuesday: "If the Government werent to accept this tomorrow, they will be staring an enormous defeat in the face."And he acknowledged that his job as a parliamentary private secretarywas on the line as a result of his actions."I have considered my position and I have tabled the amendment," he said then. "It is entirely in the hands of Government to decide who is and is not a PPS. I will continue in my role until told otherwise."In the Commons on Tuesday, Mrs May acknowledged concerns about citizens rightsher deal did not go through.She said that the Government had guaranteed "the rights of the three million EU citizens living in the UK will be protected"."But a separate agreement for citizens rights is something the EU have been clear they do not have the legal authority for," she said."If it is not done in a Withdrawal Agreement, these issues become a matter for member states unless the EU were to agree a new mandate to take this forward."Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt was seeking assurances from counterparts in EU states on the issue, she said, adding: "I urge all EU countries to make this guarantee and end the uncertainty for these citizens."

title: scottish-government-aim-to-increase-number-of-people-earning-living-wage
story: A plan to improve fairness in the workplace has been launched with a target for boosting the wages of the lowest paid.Currently .% of Scottish workers - approximately ,, people - earn at least the real Living Wage of pound per hour, but the Scottish Government want to see a % rise by .The Fair Work Action Plan also sets out measures to help employers adopt fairer working practices, including a new online Fair Work service for small firms to access support and guidance.Read more:Scotlands money: are we spending it properly It urges firms to not use "inappropriate" zero-hour contracts, for example where staff are working regular hours, tackle gender pay gaps and commit to investment in skills and training for workers.The Scottish Government warns that the fair work criteria will be applied to all appropriate grants and funding they provide for businesses, and extend the range of public sector contracts they cover.Business and fair work minister Jamie Hepburn said: "We are committed to Fair Work because it means more security, decent pay and a greater voice for workers."On top of that it drives innovation and productivity to improve businesses and increase profits. Its good for business and good for Scotland."There are many employers already championing the dimensions of fair work and there is an increasing evidence base demonstrating the benefits to workers and to business. We must build on this and convey a strong business case for Fair Work to employers across Scotland."Scotland has made and will continue to make great strides in fair work to underpin its economic success, as well as the wellbeing and prosperity of its people, communities and businesses.Read more:Government workers vote to accept new pay offer"We may not yet have the constitutional power to make fair work a legal requirement, but with this plan and the financial power of government we can try to make it a practical reality for many."Welcoming the Scottish Governments publication of the Fair Work Action Plan, Scottish Trades Union Congress general secretary Grahame Smith said: "The Fair Work Action Plan demonstrates a commitment to using the powers the Government has at its disposal to deliver fair work, which is good for workers and good for business."Through Fair Work First, it lays the foundations for ensuring that fair work is mainstreamed throughout the Scottish Governments role as a provider of major contracts and grants for business."Crucially, it recognises the fundamental importance of strong unions in achieving fair work."

title: brexit-vote-explained-what-mps-are-voting-on-and-what-amendments-mean
story: Theresa May has said MPs will get a vote on delaying Brexither deal and a no-deal outcome are both rejected.MPs will vote on amendments to a government motion in the Commons later.Debates on the Prime Ministers motion and the ious amendments up for discussion began at pmwith the votes being held at pm.The Speaker has tabled five amendments in total.Jeremy Corbyn hastabled an official amendment to push for his partys proposals for Brexit.The partys plans would see a "permanent and comprehensive" customs union with the EU and a close alignment with the single market.It is thought thatthis amendment is defeated, Jeremy Corbyns party will formally back a Peoples Vote.Read more:Jeremy Corbyn warned Peoples Vote sht will have catastrophic electoral consequences for LabourThe Labour leader insisted Theresa Mays Brexit deal won parliamentary approval, then "there must be a confirmatory public vote".The former Conservative environment secretary Caroline Spelman and Labours Jack Dromey have tabled an amendment to allow a bill to be passed that gives the Commons the chance to delay Britains exit from the EU.Read more:Theresa May offers MPs Article  delay voteIt acts as a surefire way to ensure that Theresa May abides by her promise to give MPs the power to extend Article they reject the Prime Ministers deal.Tory MP Alberto Costa has filed an amendment to seek a guarantee on the status of EU citizens, taking into consideration their status under a no-deal Brexit.The MP stepped down from hisunpaid role as parliamentary private secretaryin theScotlandOffice on Wednesday after putting forward the motion.The amendment has cross-party support fromDominic Raab, Jeremy Corbyn, Jacob Rees-Mogg, Dominic Grieve and Iain Duncan Smith.The Scottish and Welsh parties have tabled a motion, lead by Ian Blackford andLiz Saville Roberts, to show that the Commons "is determined not to leave the European Union without a withdrawal agreement and future framework under any circumstances, and regardless of any exit date.".In another bid to ensure the Prime Minister stays true to her promise to allow MPs to vote to avoid a no-deal, Labours Yvette Cooper and ConservativesSir Oliver Letwin have submitted an amendment to ensure an extension to Article .Read more:What are key points of no-deal Brexit Bill It says thatParliament rejects her deal on March  and thereafter rejects a no-deal Brexit, she must bring forward a short limited extension to Article  on March .

title: brexit-vote-commons-rejects-labour-amendment
story: Defeat of the partys amendment, which was voted down by  votes to , will put immense pressure on Corbyn to throw his partys full weight behind demands for a second EU referendum.Mr Corbyn told Labour MPs on Monday that he was ready to support moves to demand a public vote "to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit being forced on the country".Theresa Mays dramatic announcement on Tuesday that she would allow MPs to vote on delaying the UKs EU withdrawal beyond March  took the sting out of an evening of Brext votes which had been expected to feature a number of ministerial resignations.Any Conservative bust-ups have now been delayed for up to two weeks, as Mrs May prepares to bring her Withdrawal Agreement back to the Commons for a "meaningful vote" by March .If she fails to overturn the -vote mauling the Agreement received in January, votes will be held on the following days on blocking a no-deal Brexit on March  and extending the two-year Article  negotiation process.Mrs Mays U-turn threw a spotlight on the Labour leader, whose "constructive ambiguity" on Brexit has long frustrated those in his party who back a so-called Peoples Vote and played a part in the defection of eight MPs to the new Independent Group last week.Labours annual conference voted to keep a second referendum on the table, but made clear that the partys priority was an early election to allow it to implement its Brexit plan for a customs union with a UK say, close ties with the single market and dynamic alignment with EU workplace and environmental regulations.Read more:Brexit vote explained: What MPs are voting on and what amendments meanSpeaking to MPs on Monday, Mr Corbyn said that Labour would put forward its plans in an amendment to the Governments Brexit motion, but was also committed to "putting forward or supporting an amendment in favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit being forced on the country".A briefing note to Labour MPs made clear the party would back the inclusion of Remaining in the EU on the ballot paper, as an alternative to a "credible Leave option", but would not back no-deal being a choice on offer.Mr Corbyn failed to back a referendum amendment tabled by Independent Group MP Anna Soubry, which was not selected for debate on Wednesday by Speaker John Bercow.But anti-Brexit campaigners will hope that he will now give his full support to the Peoples Vote cause.Speaking ahead of the vote, a Labour spokesman sidestepped questions on when the party would back a second referendumtheir amendment was amended.The spokesman said: "We support a public vote in order to prevent no-deal or a damaging Tory Brexit. Our focus is on our credible alternative plan."Mr Corbyns plan was supported in Wednesday nights vote by Conservative former chancellor Kenneth Clarke and Liberal Democrat deputy leader Jo Swinson. All other Liberal Democrat MPs abstained.MPs later rejected a Scottish National Party amendment to rule out a no-deal Brexit in any circumstances and at any time by a margin of -.And a proposal from Conservative backbencher Alberto Costa for a UK EU treaty to protect expat citizens rights in the event of a no-deal was passed without a vote.Mr Costa quit his position as an unpaid parliamentary aide in the Scotland Office, despite Home Secretary Sajid Javid saying he supported his proposal and Downing Street making clear that Mrs May does not oppose it.A Number  source said the South Leicestershire MP had breached a long-standing convention that members of the administration - including parliamentary private secretaries- cannot table amendments to Government motions.But Labour said he had effectively been sacked. Shadow home secretary Diane Abbott said his removal "prolongs the anxiety and uncertainty that over five million people have faced for two and a half years".A cross-party amendment designed to give Parliament the power to force a vote on extending Article  was pulled, after its tablers - Conservative Dame Caroline Spelman and Labours Jack Dromey - received assurances that Mrs Mays plan would have the same effect.In a joint statement, they said: "The Government has just confirmed acceptance of all the proposals in our amendments. There will not now be a no-deal Brexit In  days time because there is not a majority in the House for crashing out without a deal."We will not plunge over the clf on March  into an abyss, making the country poorer in every sense of the word. There will now be an extension of the Brexit deadline to allow for serious cross-party dialogue on a better deal to protect the British national interest."

title: the-penny-drops-the-public-toilets-in-scotland-saved-by-plan-to-turn-them-into-tourist-info-centres
story: Some  public conveniences had faced the axe across Moray to save pound, - having already lost  in the past six years. With Scotlands  local authorities under pressure to save every penny there have been new concerns that councils, which are not legally required to provide toilets, are increasingly looking to offload the responsibility for them or close them to cut costs.Last month, a Herald study found that as of September, one in three of Scotlandrsquos remaining public toilets face being sold off or closed as councils battle to balance the books, sparking calls for them to become a human right.Now Aberdeen is currently considering shutting all ten of its public conveniences to save pound, and Highland, another tourism-leaning area, has  of its  public toilets, the most in Scotland, but have cut  in the past five years, and have five more facing the possible axe with a further  under scrutiny with plans for either partnerships or estment.In Moray, councillors and tourist chiefs have come up with a novel way to save their public toilets from the axe.An amendment supported by councillors yesterday suggests that the the toilets should remain open and under the control of the council for another year as discussions take place over whether to turn them into tourism hotspots, providing visitors with wi-fi and screens offering local information.Speyside Glenlivet councillor Derek Ross said the stay of execution will allow for a plan to be put in place to work out how the toilets can be used, and who will own them in the future."I am pleased the councillors accepted the amendment, sotoilets are safe for the time being.One of the jewels in the Moray crown: Cullen"I wanted to have them kept open go give communities time to put in place initiatives to keep the toilets open, to consult with them and look at a iety of funding sources."We are keeping them open for another year. I would prefer to keep them open, full stop, because it is one of the services that councils should provide. But the way things are going, councils are looking to save money wherever they can."Moray Speyside Tourism and The Joint Community Councils of Moray can offer expertise and advice, and work collaboratively with communities to try and help them out and they would then be independent of the council."The popularity of TV series Outlander has been credited with bringing overseas tourists to Scotland with whisky and the coastline proving to be Morayrsquos biggest draws.Jobs supported by the tourism industry across the area are now nearing , as visitors spend almost .million nights a year in the region enjoying the sights Laurie Piper, managing director of Moray Speyside Tourism, believes the toilets in the region could be kept through ersication.Mr Ross said transforming the the toilets into tourism information areas would be a ldquogreat idea."They could be use to help point visitors in the direction of tourist attractions in the area," said Mr Ross. "Tourism is valuable to the area and toilets play an important part in the infrastructure that underpins that industry. "I say the ideas that Laurie is putting should be given a chance."Mr Piper said: ldquoI think we should look together at creative ways to create a solution and offer a sustainable  for the operation of those facilities.ldquoI would be keen to work with the council and the JCC to create a long-term sustainable future for the toilets for the benefit of the tourism business although this is reliant on the tourism BID projected to be approved.ldquoIt would take two or three years to put together. Money and time would be needed.Herald research showed that as of September there were  council-run public toilets around Scotland -  fewer than in .And  further free conveniences had their futures under question either because local authorities are looking to offload them through new ownership or they are up for closure.Pressure group the British Toilet Association which fears those under review could also end up disappearing has called for public toilets to become a human right enshrined in law and want legislation that forces councils to provide enough facilities for the elderly, disabled people or tourists.

title: tory-brexiteers-defy-may-over-vote-to-extend-article-50-process-to-delay-exit-day
story: In a series of Commons votes, an amendment tabled by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper, which underscored the Prime Ministerrsquos promise, saw  members of the anti-EU European Research Group vote against it while only  Tories of the partys  MPs, eligible to vote, gave it their support.Labourrsquos own plan for a permanent customs union with the EU was again defeated by  votes to , a majority of .While Labour MPs called for the party leadership to now swing ldquowholeheartedly behind a Peoplersquos Vote, Jeremy Corbyn said he would continue to push for a version of his Brexit plan despite the signicant rejection by MPs.Meanwhile, David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary, stressed the Commons had "endorsed the PMs approach" to have a series of votes next month and he stressed the best way to "avoid a no-deal outcome" was to vote for Mrs Mays deal in the next meaningful parliamentary vote.

title: tv-review-debate-night-making-sense-of-the-news-or-just-a-snooze
story: Particularly so after it emerged the man at the centre of the row, failed UKIP candidate Billy Mitchell, had not just appeared on Question Time four times, in breach of the showrsquos rules, but he had also taken part in a pilot for Debate Night.Five hurdles for new BBC channelWith Mr Mitchell seemingly able to do a Paul McKenna on researchers, it was not impossible that he would turn up again last night when the show made its official debut.Debate Night producers were on the case, however. As a look at the audience application form showed, the love grandchild of Senator Joseph McCarthy and a top Stasi agent is now in charge of selection. There are more questions, requiring a greater level of detail, than the regular QT form, with applicants asked how they would vote in an indyref, how they voted in the Scottish Parliament elections , and whether they are members of a political party. If it is yes to the latter, they need to specy which party, and whether they have ever held an elected position or worked for a party. Phew. They might as well ask for an armful of blood while they are at it.Last nightrsquos programme came from Edinburgh. In place of Fiona Bruce there was Stephen Jardine, son of Dumfries, ex-GMTV and Scottish Television. As a frequent stand-in host on BBC Radio Scotland morning shout-fest, Call Kaye, you could see why he had been given the gig.Magic or mince  You decideDebate Night made the news before last night when it emerged the budget for the show was so small it could not afford to move around the country, like QT. Whatever they have spent the money on, it is not the set. With its purple chairs and faux art it looked like the business class lounge of a cheapo airline. The audience were in cinema-style banked seating which made the audience look tiny. Worse, some of the seats were empty.But never mind the standard of the seating, what about the quality of the debate  The audience, Jardine informed us, came from all across Scotland, ldquofrom Ayrshire to Paisley, Perth and Edinburgh. In other words, from a bus ride away.On the  were three politicians, Deputy FM John Swinney, Labourrsquos Monica Lennon, and Murdo Fraser for the Scottish Conservatives, and two civilians, the poet Jenny Lindsay and the entrepreneur Sir Tom Hunter. Two women to three men, or two to fouryou count Jardine: some things never change. No Greens or LibDems will it be their turn next week Marks out of  for The Nine The job of the new show, Jardine said in his introduction, was not just to get answers from politicians but to raise the standard of debate, no less. Within a minute, however, Murdo Fraser was talking over Monica Lennon and she was raising her own voice in response. So much for new standards of discourse. It was not long, either, before the politicians on the  began answering the questions that suited them rather than the ones they had been asked. Jardine pulled a Paxman now and then, possibly to shake himself awake. ldquoWhat does any of this mean, what are you going to do about it  he asked Lennon at one point.Half an hour was spent on Brexit, far too long. The next questions, on sectarianism and a possible teachersrsquo pay strike, were not matters that would have been raised on a QT from London, so in that respect Debate Night showed its worth, evennothing new emerged in the discussion.I would like to say the hour was packed with penetrating questions and illuminating answers, a show that showed QT how such programmes should be done. There were one or two moments worth catching, most of them coming from plain-speaking Sir Tom Hunter, but by and large this was a punishing watch, not least because of the late slot. An .pm finish, on a school night  Why bother committing to a serious programmeit doesnrsquot have a credible chance of building an audience By the time Jardine said goodnight it was time for this Cinderella to head to bed. Cinders at least had her slipper ed those  minutes spent watching Debate Night are never coming back.

title: firm s ice cream sales heat up
story: A scorching summer and increased exports has helped a north east firm achieve record revenues and profits from ice cream sales in .Mackie’s of Scotland has reported a record annual turnover of £. million and gross profit exceeding £. million for the financial year ending May .The company’s turnover was up % on the previous year thanks in part to boosted ice cream sales in supermarkets across the UK, increasing sales in the Far East, the addition of a range of chocolate bars and revenue from production of renewable energy on the Mackie’s farm at Westertown.Mackie’s enjoyed record-breaking sales in , with £. million turnover reported for ice cream and chocolate. Meanwhile its export sales to markets in the Far East soared by % to £. million - now contributing % to its total turnover.The company’s net assets were up by % and operating profit continued to rise, standing at £. million, with profits reinvested into the company, extending production with items like a new packaging machine in addition to investment in the Aberdeen ice cream parlour.Overall costs increased by % on the previous year, due in part to the continued high price of cream. Although its own -strong cow herd helps to buffer the impact of rising cream prices, during peak times in particular, the firm is required to buy extra cream at market prices.Mac Mackie, Managing Director at Mackie’s and one of three sibling owners, said: “ was certainly a signicant year for Mackie’s, with substantial growth in our export trade as well as developments closer to home.“Our current financial year has started well with the hot summer months with growth continuing into .” Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: james going for gold in gordon
story: The Liberal Democrats have selected their next candidate to be in the running for Gordon#s MP seat.The party has chosen James Oates, the nephew of long-serving former Gordon MP Malcolm Bruce.After graduating from Aberdeen University  years ago, he became a campaigner for human rights in Central and Eastern Europe.Multi-lingual, he later worked in the region for large investment firms such as JP Morgan, Robert Fleming and UBS, and for the past ten years he has been working with technology businesses in Tallinn, Estonia and building investment across the region.Commenting Mr Oates said: “I’m running to be Gordon’s MP because our country needs and wants to change. “It’s time to bring new energy, after the negativity of the past four years. It’s time for us to look the prosperity of the future and let go of the failed politics of the past.“It’s time for a new commitment to make sure that the opportunities in Gordon and in all of Scotland are recognised by the whole of the United Kingdom. Our contributions are not appreciated and our needs have been ignored for far too long.”He added: “I will not be one of those MPs that sits in London ignoring the people who put him there in the first place.“If I learned anything from Malcolm, it’s that cooperation, effective representation and respect for our communities are the most important traits I could have. My door will always be open.“I will bring Gordon and the needs of the Northeast to the Government, not the other way around.“It’s time our voices were heard again.” Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: oldmeldrum publican loses 2am licencing bid
story: An Oldmeldrum publican believes others in the trade are #wasting their time# applying for a am drinks licence after a failed bid by his own premises.Robin Philip, owner of Morris’s Hotel, was unsuccessful in his application for an extra hour on a Friday and Saturday for his public bar in a bid to boost dwindling trade.Dficult trading times in an economic climate hampered by increases in business rates and operating costs had prompted his application to extend weekend drinking times.However Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board stuck to its policies which limits pubs and hotels to a am licence but which offers nightclubs am licences Sunday to Thursday and am on Fridays and Saturdays.The board had earlier heard objections to the later opening element of the application from Sgt Kim Wood on behalf of Police Scotland who said there was clear evidence that the longer and later on-sales licensed premises operate, the “higher the likelihood of incidents of crime, disorder and anti-social behaviour occurring”.But the Oldmeldrum publican stressed he had not experienced trouble in the  years he has run his business.He said the public bar only held  patrons who merely wanted to enjoy a slightly longer night out on a Saturday.Mr Philip said the crime figures presented by the police were for Ellon and Inverurie and had no bearing on Oldmeldrum.A motion by Cllr Marion Ewenson to approve elements of the application, including an outdoor drinking area, with the exception of the am Friday and Saturday extension, was unanimously approved.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: partnership for dentist and foodbank
story: An Inverurie dentist has teamed up with a local foodbank in a bid to offer much-needed support.Inverurie Smile Care has become formal Community Partners of the Inverurie Foodbank Centre.The Inverurie Foodbank Centre is part of Aberdeenshire North Foodbank, which has other food distribution centres in Ellon, Peterhead and Huntly as well as a central warehouse just outside Inverurie.The Foodbank Centre has been running in the town since .In  the Inverurie Foodbank Distribution Centre fulfilled  food parcel vouchers, providing food for the equivalent of  adults and  children - an  percent increase from .Commenting Debbie Rennie, Foodbank manager, said: “It is clear through their support of us since  and through recent discussions with them that they understand the need for the work that we are doing in the community and it is fantastic that they are supporting us with regular donations.“As much as we are worried about growing numbers of people needing emergency food parcels, what is positive about all of our Foodbank Centres, including Inverurie, is that local communities are coming together to meet local need through donating food, like Inverurie Smile Care have committed to doing, donating services, and the work of the foodbanks are predominantly done by local volunteers, which is so valuable.”Mohammed Khan, group marketing manager at Inverurie Smile Care added: “Be it regular foodbank donations, or sponsoring the Inverurie Academy Football teams, Smile Care are proud to be involved with the town of Inverurie: such engagement being a major, contributing factor to our award as ‘Scotland’s Best NHS Dental Practice’ at the Dentistry Scotland Awards .”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Thursday  Feb  : AM
